questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 37 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. Her current pregnancy has been complicated by iron deficiency anemia treated with iron tablets. She has received routine prenatal care, but she has not been tested for group B streptococcal (GBS) colonization. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were complicated by an infection with GBS that resulted in sepsis in the newborn. The patient has no history of serious illness. Current medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is nontender and contractions are felt every 4 minutes. There is clear amniotic fluid pooling in the vagina. The fetus is in a cephalic presentation. The fetal heart rate is 140/min. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain vaginal-rectal swab for GBS culture and intravenous penicillin administration
Obtain vaginal-rectal swab for GBS culture
Obtain vaginal-rectal swab for nucleic acid amplification testing and intravenous penicillin administration

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Culture of GBS is usually indicated at 36 0/7–37 6/7 weeks' gestation for diagnosis of maternal GBS colonization. Intrapartum administration of intravenous penicillin G is used for the prophylaxis of neonatal GBS infection. Indications for prophylaxis include maternal GBS colonization, GBS bacteriuria occurring during pregnancy, or a history of a previous newborn with GBS infection (as in this patient). Because this patient already has an indication for prophylaxis, GBS screening cultures are not required.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient is most likely colonized by GBS and should receive a different intervention to avoid intrapartum transmission and a subsequent negative outcome in her unborn child.

C) INCORRECT:

Culture of GBS is indicated at 36 0/7–37 6/7 weeks' gestation for diagnosis of maternal GBS colonization. However, patients with GBS bacteriuria during pregnancy or a history of a previous newborn with GBS infection (as in this patient) require prophylaxis. Therefore, she does not require further testing, as it would not influence the treatment.

D) CORRECT:

Intrapartum administration of intravenous penicillin G is used for the prophylaxis of neonatal GBS infection. Maternal GBS colonization is a major risk factor for early-onset neonatal infection and sepsis. Routine screening for GBS colonization of all pregnant women via culture of vaginal and rectal swabs is indicated between 36 0/7–37 6/7 weeks' gestation. Women with GBS bacteriuria occurring anytime during pregnancy or history of a previous newborn with GBS infection, as in this patient, should receive routine prophylactic antibiotics and do not have to undergo prior screening for GBS colonization.

Other maternal risk factors for GBS infection that serve as indications for antibiotic prophylaxis in patients with unknown antepartum culture status include fever, preterm labor, premature rupture of membranes, or positive intrapartum nucleic acid amplification testing for GBS.

E) INCORRECT:

Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) can be used for rapid intrapartum diagnosis of maternal GBS colonization in women with an unknown culture status. However, NAAT is not routinely used because of its low sensitivity compared to standard GBS culture. Moreover, the management of cases with a possible maternal GBS colonization and an unknown antepartum culture status should be based on maternal risk factors rather than NAAT results. Intrapartum administration of intravenous penicillin G is used for the prophylaxis of neonatal GBS infection.

F) INCORRECT:

Colonization or active infections (e.g., chorioamnionitis) do not routinely justify a cesarean delivery. However, if an infection presents along with fetal distress or there is any other standard obstetric indication (e.g., insufficient maternal contractions), the patient would require a cesarean delivery.
questions.hint: This patient's first child had sepsis due to a GBS infection. It is essential to prevent the infection from recurring in her second child.

questions.text: A previously healthy 29-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 35 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal visit. Current medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. A rectovaginal swab culture grows bacitracin-resistant colonies of gram-positive cocci with surrounding areas of clear hemolysis. Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention to decrease vertical transmission of this organism?

choices.text: Schedule delivery of the fetus via C-section

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Scheduling delivery of the fetus via C-section would not be appropriate for this patient. Colonization with GBS or active infection (e.g., chorioamnionitis) is not a routine indication for C-section. Cesarean deliveries are reserved for patients with standard obstetric indications (e.g., insufficient maternal contractions, fetal malposition, cephalopelvic disproportion) or severe infections that present along with fetal distress.

B) INCORRECT:

Benzathine penicillin G is used in the treatment of syphilis and infection with Streptococcus pyogenes (which is sensitive to bacitracin, unlike the organism cultured in this patient). While GBS infection can also be treated with penicillin G, administration of the antibiotic at this time would not be appropriate because it does not eliminate the risk of recolonization at the time of delivery.

C) INCORRECT:

Abstaining from breastfeeding due to a group B streptococcal (GBS) infection would not be appropriate in this patient. GBS can be passed to the neonate during delivery but not through breast milk. Reasons to permanently abstain from breastfeeding include maternal infections with retroviruses (e.g., HIV and human T-cell lymphotropic virus) or ebola virus, or classic galactosemia in the infant. Indications for temporarily abstaining include active herpes infection and concomitant use of toxic medications (e.g., tetracyclines).

D) CORRECT:

Ampicillin (or penicillin G) is administered in the intrapartum period as prophylaxis for neonatal GBS disease. Maternal GBS colonization is a major risk factor for early-onset neonatal infection and sepsis. Prenatal screening for GBS colonization (culture of vaginal and rectal swabs) is indicated in all pregnant women from 36+0 to 37+6 weeks' gestation and intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis is indicated in all women with a positive screening. It is also indicated in women with GBS bacteriuria occurring any time during pregnancy and in those who have previously given birth to a newborn with GBS infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Intravenous immune globulin (IVIG) is administered postpartum as prophylaxis in several scenarios, e.g., in neonates exposed to measles or in the case of Rh incompatibility. IVIG is not indicated in patients with a swab that is positive for group B streptococcus (GBS).
questions.hint: This patient's swab culture is positive for group B streptococcus (GBS), which is a bacitracin-resistant, β-hemolytic, gram-positive coccus.

questions.text: A 29-year-old primigravid woman at 36 weeks' gestation comes for a prenatal visit. She reports some tiredness but has otherwise been well. She was successfully treated with fosfomycin for asymptomatic group B Streptococcus bacteriuria in the first trimester. She has since moved to a different state and has not attended any further routine prenatal visits. Last year, while she was being treated with amoxicillin for bacterial sinusitis, she developed a rash on her chest that resolved spontaneously. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable and her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus that is consistent in size with a 36-week gestation. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation?

choices.text: Collection of rectovaginal swab for culture
Administration of penicillin to the newborn after delivery

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's history of asymptomatic GBS bacteriuria in the first trimester warrants intrapartum GBS prophylaxis regardless of GBS culture results. Cefazolin is the antibiotic of choice for neonatal GBS prophylaxis in women who have a history of mild penicillin allergy. Patients with a high risk for anaphylaxis (e.g., a history of immediate flushing, angioedema, respiratory distress after penicillin intake) require intrapartum clindamycin, or vancomycin if GBS is resistant to clindamycin. If allergy status is unclear, penicillin skin testing should be performed prior to labor.

B) INCORRECT:

Intrapartum penicillin is indicated for intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis in patients with GBS colonization who do not have a history of anaphylactic reaction to penicillin. This patient has a history of a mild reaction to amoxicillin and therefore requires a different approach.

C) INCORRECT:

A rectovaginal swab for GBS culture is generally indicated between 36+0–37+6 weeks' gestation to determine GBS status and whether intrapartum prophylactic antibiotics are necessary to prevent neonatal GBS infection. However, in patients who have developed GBS bacteriuria at any point during the current pregnancy and in patients with a history of previous delivery of a newborn with GBS infection, intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis is indicated without prior GBS culture.

D) INCORRECT:

Administration of penicillin after delivery is indicated for all neonates with confirmed GBS infection. Vaginally delivered neonates of women with GBS colonization have a higher risk of developing early onset GBS infection. However, preventive administration of antibiotics to the neonate is not recommended.

E) INCORRECT:

A urine culture is indicated in all pregnant patients, typically at 12–16 weeks' gestation, to screen for asymptomatic bacteriuria, which is associated with adverse pregnancy outcomes (e.g., preterm labor, low birth weight). Repeat urine culture is also required around one week after treatment to ensure that the therapy has been effective. However, a urine culture in this patient has already confirmed asymptomatic GBS bacteriuria, which was successfully treated. A different intervention is indicated at this time.
questions.hint: Indications for intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis include positive screening culture for group B Streptococcus (GBS), previous delivery of a newborn with GBS infection, and GBS bacteriuria at any time during pregnancy.

questions.text:
A full-term male infant born via spontaneous vaginal delivery to a 32-year-old gravida 2, para 2 mother is evaluated immediately after birth. Membranes were ruptured at the time of delivery, and the infant’s Apgar scores were 7 at one minute and 9 at five minutes.
The mother tested positive for group B streptococcus vaginal colonization during her third trimester and was treated with one dose of penicillin 30 minutes before delivery. She had no fever or uterine fundal tenderness during delivery or the immediate postpartum period.
The infant has mild acral cyanosis but otherwise appears well and has a normal newborn examination.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this infant?

choices.text: Obtain a complete blood count and blood culture, and treat empirically with ampicillin and gentamicin
Obtain a blood culture, and defer antibiotic treatment unless cultures show evidence of bacteremia
Obtain a chest radiograph, and provide empiric treatment with ampicillin and gentamicin
Administer a dose of intramuscular penicillin

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Group B streptococcus (GBS or Streptococcus agalactiae) is a gram-positive bacterium that colonizes up to 40% of pregnant women. It is an important cause of neonatal disease when transmitted vertically to an infant during delivery. Early-onset disease occurs in the first week of life and typically manifests as sepsis, pneumonia, or meningitis. Late-onset disease occurs after the first week of life and typically manifests as sepsis or meningitis; on rare occasions, it manifests as bone or soft-tissue infection.

All women should undergo culture-based screening for vaginal and rectal GBS colonization at 35 to 37 weeks’ gestation. Those who test positive should receive intravenous penicillin every 4 hours from the onset of labor or membrane rupture until delivery. In the setting of penicillin allergy, clindamycin, vancomycin, or cefazolin may be used; however, clindamycin or vancomycin alone is not considered adequate intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis. Susceptibility testing should be done if clindamycin is used for prophylaxis. In the setting of maternal GBS bacteriuria during the current pregnancy or maternal history of a prior infant with invasive GBS infection, women do not require GBS screening cultures and should be treated with intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis.

A minimum of 4 hours of intrapartum antibiotics is considered adequate prophylaxis. In cases where a GBS-positive mother receives inadequate prophylaxis and the infant appears well, the next step depends on the gestational age of the infant, highest maternal antepartum temperature, timing of membrane rupture, type and duration of maternal intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis, and clinical examination of the infant after birth. Many centers are moving toward the use of multivariate risk assessment (e.g., Neonatal Early-Onset Sepsis Calculator) in an effort to more accurately predict an infant’s risk for early-onset sepsis and reduce unnecessary neonatal antibiotic administration when clinically appropriate.

Key learning point: For a well-appearing, full-term neonate born via spontaneous vaginal delivery to a mother who had group B streptococcus vaginal colonization, received inadequate intrapartum antibiotics, and did not have prolonged rupture of membranes, the most appropriate management approach is 48 hours of observation.

B) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotic coverage and further workup — including complete blood count, blood culture, lumbar puncture, and chest radiograph — would potentially be indicated if the infant had additional risk factors or was showing clinical signs or symptoms concerning for early-onset sepsis.

C) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotic coverage and further workup — including complete blood count, blood culture, lumbar puncture, and chest radiograph — would potentially be indicated if the infant had additional risk factors or was showing clinical signs or symptoms concerning for early-onset sepsis.

D) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotic coverage and further workup — including complete blood count, blood culture, lumbar puncture, and chest radiograph — would potentially be indicated if the infant had additional risk factors or was showing clinical signs or symptoms concerning for early-onset sepsis.

E) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotic coverage would potentially be indicated if the infant had additional risk factors or was showing clinical signs or symptoms concerning for early-onset sepsis.

Current medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. A rectovaginal swab culture grows Streptococcus agalactiae. Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention to decrease vertical transmission of this organism?

questions.hint: Group B Streptococcus (GBS) is a bacitracin-resistant, β-hemolytic, gram-positive coccus.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman delivers spontaneously at 34 weeks. On day 1, the infant is febrile and irritable. Blood cultures confirm Group B Streptococcus. Which factor most likely predisposed him?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fetal macrosomia, characterized by excessive birth weight, is often related to maternal diabetes and does not correlate with neonatal Group B Streptococcus (GBS) infection risk. GBS sepsis results from vertical transmission during delivery, with risk factors including preterm delivery and inadequate intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis, not fetal macrosomia.

B) CORRECT:

Preterm infants have an underdeveloped immune system, with reduced transplacental transfer of maternal immunoglobulin G and an immature innate immune response, increasing susceptibility to infections like Group B Streptococcus (GBS). Preterm labor can also limit the time for effective intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis. The pathophysiology of neonatal GBS infection involves the organism exploiting the neonate's limited immune defenses, particularly in preterm infants.

Key learning point: Preterm birth is a recognized risk factor for Group B Streptococcus infection in newborns due to their underdeveloped immune systems.

C) INCORRECT:

Delayed breastfeeding initiation does not significantly impact early-onset Group B Streptococcus (GBS) sepsis, which results from vertical transmission during labor. The neonate's symptoms on day 1 align with intrapartum-acquired infections, not postnatal factors like breastfeeding timing.

D) INCORRECT:

Inadequate maternal iron supplementation is not linked to neonatal Group B Streptococcus (GBS) infection. Early-onset GBS disease is primarily due to vertical transmission from a colonized maternal genital tract, influenced by maternal GBS screening and intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis, not maternal nutritional status.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old G2P1 woman at 39 weeks’ gestation is admitted to the Labor Unit with regular contractions. A rectovaginal culture at 36 weeks was positive for group B streptococci. She has no known medication allergies. Her cervix is dilated to 5 cm, and membranes ruptured spontaneously an hour ago with clear fluid. Vital signs are stable, and continuous fetal monitoring shows normal tracings.
Which of the following is the most appropriate intrapartum management to reduce the risk of early-onset GBS disease in her newborn?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin, while effective against GBS, is unsuitable for intrapartum prophylaxis due to its slower absorption and less reliable therapeutic levels. Intravenous administration is preferred to rapidly achieve effective maternal and fetal serum concentrations, ensuring timely bacterial suppression during labor.

B) CORRECT:

Intravenous ampicillin is the standard intrapartum prophylaxis for group B streptococcus (GBS) colonization to prevent early-onset neonatal sepsis. Ampicillin, a beta-lactam antibiotic, disrupts bacterial cell wall synthesis and is effective against gram-positive organisms like GBS. Administering it intravenously during labor ensures rapid therapeutic levels, minimizing vertical transmission. Guidelines from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) recommend this approach for GBS-positive women without beta-lactam allergies, as it provides reliable bioavailability and optimal pharmacologic action during the critical intrapartum period.

Key learning point: Intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis with Ampicillin is recommended for pregnant women who are Group-B streptococci positive to prevent early-onset GBS disease in the newborn.

C) INCORRECT:

Forgoing antibiotic prophylaxis is inappropriate for a GBS-positive patient, as it increases the risk of early-onset neonatal infections. Established guidelines recommend antibiotics for GBS-positive women to prevent neonatal sepsis, pneumonia, and meningitis, especially when no contraindications exist.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous vancomycin is reserved for patients with severe beta-lactam allergies. This patient has no known allergies, making beta-lactam antibiotics like penicillin the preferred choice. Vancomycin's broader spectrum and resistance risk make it less suitable when beta-lactams are an option.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old G2P1 woman at 30 weeks’ gestation presents to the clinic with regular painful contractions. She has had no prenatal care and is uncertain of her group B streptococcus status. She denies any drug allergies. Examination shows her cervix is effaced and dilated to 3 cm. Fetal heart rate tracing is reassuring. Tocolysis is being initiated, and betamethasone has been administered for fetal lung maturity.
Which of the following is the most appropriate step to reduce the risk of neonatal group B streptococcal infection in this patient?

choices.text: Defer antibiotic prophylaxis unless GBS culture is positive

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin, although effective against group B Streptococcus, does not achieve the rapid and consistent maternal serum concentrations required for intrapartum prophylaxis. Oral administration leads to variable absorption and pharmacokinetics, insufficient for timely therapeutic levels during labor. The intravenous route is necessary for immediate antibiotic levels critical during labor.

B) CORRECT:

Intravenous penicillin G is the standard intrapartum prophylactic antibiotic to prevent vertical transmission of group B Streptococcus (GBS) during labor, especially when GBS status is unknown. Administering IV penicillin G reduces the risk of neonatal GBS infection by targeting the bacteria at its transmission source during delivery. Clinical guidelines recommend intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis in women in preterm labor, as early-onset GBS disease is a major cause of neonatal morbidity and mortality. Penicillin G's narrow spectrum and efficacy in clearing GBS from the maternal genital tract decrease the risk of neonatal sepsis, pneumonia, and meningitis.

Key learning point: In preterm labor at 30 weeks gestation, management includes administering corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity, tocolytics to delay labor, and GBS prophylaxis to prevent neonatal infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone, a broad-spectrum cephalosporin, is not aligned with intrapartum prophylaxis protocols for GBS. Effective prophylaxis requires intravenous administration to rapidly achieve therapeutic serum levels. Intramuscular injections result in delayed and less predictable concentrations, which is suboptimal during labor. Guidelines recommend beta-lactam agents like penicillin for patients without allergies.

D) INCORRECT:

Deferring antibiotic prophylaxis until a positive GBS culture is confirmed is inappropriate in preterm labor with unknown GBS status. Delaying prophylaxis can miss the window for effective intrapartum antibiotic administration, exposing the neonate to GBS infection risks. Guidelines advocate for prophylaxis in patients with risk factors like preterm labor or unknown GBS colonization.

questions.text: You are caring for a 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 37 weeks' gestation who is admitted to the hospital in active labor. She has received routine prenatal care but has not been tested for group B streptococcal (GBS) colonization. Her previous pregnancy and delivery were complicated by a GBS infection that resulted in neonatal sepsis. Her current medications are folic acid and a multivitamin. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are normal. The abdomen is nontender, and contractions occur every 4 minutes. There is clear amniotic fluid pooling in the vagina. The fetus is in cephalic presentation, and the fetal heart rate is 140/min. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain vaginal-rectal swab for GBS culture.
Obtain vaginal-rectal swab for nucleic acid amplification testing and intravenous penicillin administration.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Colonization or active infections (e.g., chorioamnionitis) do not routinely justify a cesarean delivery. However, if an infection presents along with fetal distress or there is any other standard obstetric indication (e.g., insufficient maternal contractions), the patient would require a cesarean delivery.

However, patients with GBS bacteriuria during pregnancy or a history of a previous newborn with GBS infection (as in this patient) require prophylaxis. Therefore, she does not require further testing, as it would not influence the treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient is most likely colonized by GBS and should receive a different intervention to avoid intrapartum transmission and a subsequent negative outcome in her unborn child.

D) INCORRECT:

Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) can be used for rapid intrapartum diagnosis of maternal GBS colonization in women with an unknown culture status. However, NAAT is not routinely used because of its low sensitivity compared to standard GBS culture. Moreover, the management of cases with a possible maternal GBS colonization and an unknown antepartum culture status should be based on maternal risk factors rather than NAAT results. Intrapartum administration of intravenous penicillin G is used for the prophylaxis of neonatal GBS infection.

E) CORRECT:

Intrapartum administration of intravenous penicillin G is used for the prophylaxis of neonatal GBS infection. Maternal GBS colonization is a major risk factor for early-onset neonatal infection and sepsis. Routine screening for GBS colonization of all pregnant women via culture of vaginal and rectal swabs is indicated between 36 0/7–37 6/7 weeks' gestation. Women with GBS bacteriuria occurring anytime during pregnancy or history of a previous newborn with GBS infection, as in this patient, should receive routine prophylactic antibiotics and do not have to undergo prior screening for GBS colonization.

Other maternal risk factors for GBS infection that serve as indications for antibiotic prophylaxis in patients with unknown antepartum culture status include fever, preterm labor, premature rupture of membranes, or positive intrapartum nucleic acid amplification testing for GBS.

Key learning point: Women with a history of a previous newborn with GBS infection should receive intrapartum intravenous penicillin for neonatal GBS prophylaxis without the need for additional screening.
questions.hint: This patient's first child had sepsis due to a GBS infection. It is essential to prevent the infection from recurring in her second child.

Membranes ruptured at the time of delivery. Apgar scores were 7 at one minute and 9 at five minutes. The mother tested positive for group B streptococcus vaginal colonization during her third trimester and received one dose of penicillin 30 minutes before delivery. She had no fever or uterine fundal tenderness during delivery or in the immediate postpartum period. The infant has mild acral cyanosis, but the newborn examination is normal. Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this infant?

choices.text: Administer a dose of intramuscular penicillin.
Obtain a chest radiograph, and provide empiric treatment with ampicillin and gentamicin.
Obtain a blood culture, and defer antibiotic treatment unless cultures show evidence of bacteremia.
Obtain a complete blood count and blood culture, and treat empirically with ampicillin and gentamicin.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotic coverage would potentially be indicated if the infant had additional risk factors or was showing clinical signs or symptoms concerning for early-onset sepsis.

B) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotic coverage and further workup — including complete blood count, blood culture, lumbar puncture, and chest radiograph — would potentially be indicated if the infant had additional risk factors or was showing clinical signs or symptoms concerning for early-onset sepsis.

C) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotic coverage and further workup — including complete blood count, blood culture, lumbar puncture, and chest radiograph — would potentially be indicated if the infant had additional risk factors or was showing clinical signs or symptoms concerning for early-onset sepsis.

D) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotic coverage and further workup — including complete blood count, blood culture, lumbar puncture, and chest radiograph — would potentially be indicated if the infant had additional risk factors or was showing clinical signs or symptoms concerning for early-onset sepsis.

E) CORRECT:

All women should undergo culture-based screening for vaginal and rectal GBS colonization at 36+0 to 37+6 weeks’ gestation. Those who test positive should receive intravenous penicillin every 4 hours from the onset of labor or membrane rupture until delivery. In the setting of penicillin allergy, clindamycin, vancomycin, or cefazolin may be used; however, clindamycin or vancomycin alone is not considered adequate intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis. Susceptibility testing should be done if clindamycin is used for prophylaxis. In the setting of maternal GBS bacteriuria during the current pregnancy or maternal history of a prior infant with invasive GBS infection, women do not require GBS screening cultures and should be treated with intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis.

A minimum of 4 hours of intrapartum antibiotics is considered adequate prophylaxis. In cases where a GBS-positive mother receives inadequate prophylaxis and the infant appears well, the next step depends on the gestational age of the infant, highest maternal antepartum temperature, timing of membrane rupture, type and duration of maternal intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis, and clinical examination of the infant after birth. Many centers are moving toward the use of multivariate risk assessment (e.g., Neonatal Early-Onset Sepsis Calculator) in an effort to more accurately predict an infant’s risk for early-onset sepsis and reduce unnecessary neonatal antibiotic administration when clinically appropriate.

Early-onset disease occurs in the first week of life and typically manifests as sepsis, pneumonia, or meningitis. Late-onset disease occurs after the first week of life and typically manifests as sepsis or meningitis; on rare occasions, it manifests as bone or soft-tissue infection.

Key learning point: For a well-appearing, full-term neonate born via spontaneous vaginal delivery to a mother who had group B streptococcus vaginal colonization, received inadequate intrapartum antibiotics, and did not have prolonged rupture of membranes, the most appropriate management approach is 48 hours of observation.
questions.hint: Group B streptococcus (GBS or Streptococcus agalactiae) is a gram-positive bacterium that colonizes up to 40% of pregnant women. It is an important cause of neonatal disease when transmitted vertically to an infant during delivery.

questions.text: You are seeing a previously healthy 29-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 35 weeks' gestation for a routine prenatal visit. Her current medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. A rectovaginal swab culture is positive for Streptococcus agalactiae. Which one of the following is the most appropriate intervention to decrease vertical transmission of this organism?

choices.text: Schedule delivery of the fetus via C-section.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Abstaining from breastfeeding due to a group B streptococcal (GBS) infection would not be appropriate in this patient. GBS can be passed to the neonate during delivery but not through breast milk. Reasons to permanently abstain from breastfeeding include maternal infections with retroviruses (e.g., HIV and human T-cell lymphotropic virus) or ebola virus, or classic galactosemia in the infant. Indications for temporarily abstaining include active herpes infection and concomitant use of toxic medications (e.g., tetracyclines).

B) INCORRECT:

Benzathine penicillin G is used in the treatment of syphilis and infection with Streptococcus pyogenes (which is sensitive to bacitracin, unlike the organism cultured in this patient). While GBS infection can also be treated with penicillin G, administration of the antibiotic at this time would not be appropriate because it does not eliminate the risk of recolonization at the time of delivery.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravenous immune globulin (IVIG) is administered postpartum as prophylaxis in several scenarios, e.g., in neonates exposed to measles or in the case of Rh incompatibility. IVIG is not indicated in patients with a swab that is positive for group B streptococcus (GBS).

D) CORRECT:

Ampicillin (or penicillin G) is administered in the intrapartum period as prophylaxis for neonatal GBS disease. Maternal GBS colonization is a major risk factor for early-onset neonatal infection and sepsis. Prenatal screening for GBS colonization (culture of vaginal and rectal swabs) is indicated in all pregnant women from 36+0 to 37+6 weeks' gestation and intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis is indicated in all women with a positive screening. It is also indicated in women with GBS bacteriuria occurring any time during pregnancy and in those who have previously given birth to a newborn with GBS infection.

Key learning point: Intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis with penicillin or ampicillin is given to GBS-positive pregnant women during labor to prevent neonatal group B streptococcal infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Scheduling delivery of the fetus via C-section would not be appropriate for this patient. Colonization with GBS or active infection (e.g., chorioamnionitis) is not a routine indication for C-section. Cesarean deliveries are reserved for patients with standard obstetric indications (e.g., insufficient maternal contractions, fetal malposition, cephalopelvic disproportion) or severe infections that present along with fetal distress.
questions.hint: Group B Streptococcus (GBS) is a bacitracin-resistant, β-hemolytic, gram-positive coccus.
